bioghist.p: Founded in 1743 by Benjamin Franklin, the American Philosophical Society was the first learned society in the United States. The endowment of the Society provides a substantial portion of the operating budget. The Annual Fund, which provides unrestricted operating support, was initiated in 1992 and continues to grow. Foundation grants play an important role, as do the Friends of the Library, in the support of special projects, such as the development of information retrieval systems and the refinement of conservation activities in the Library. Building campaigns have also been a significant source of funds throughout the Society's history. For example, the Benjamin Franklin Hall Campaign, begun in 1981 in conjunction with the purchase of the Farmers' and Mechanics' Bank building and continuing for over a decade, raised funds for that building's renovation to serve as a meeting and collection storage space.

scopecontent.p: This is a collection of records related to development activities at the APS. The collection documents major fundraising efforts, including the Annual Fund, the Benjamin Franklin Hall Campaign, and grant proposals to the Mellon Foundation. The Annual Fund records cover the years 1992 to 1996 and include: drafts of appeal letters; monthly reports; and letters of acknowledgment and copies of checks. Records of the Benjamin Franklin Hall Campaign (1981-1992) include: steering committee reports, planning and strategy documents, pledge projections and budgets, copies of appeals to the general membership, foundation and corporate appeals, incoming and outgoing correspondence with donors and prospects, and campaign publications, such as brochures and printed letters. Records of Mellon Foundation grants include drafts and finished copies of grant proposals, projected budgets, and correspondence. The collection also includes correspondence and planning documents from the files of John Callahan and other staff with development responsibilities. These files document fundraising efforts such as the Daland fellowship, the Lincei project, as well as various exhibitions and awards, including the Rhoads medal (1997). These files also document other projects with which Callahan was involved, such as executive searches for the Institute for Nautical Archaeology and the Delaware Theater Company, and the Russian Translation Project.

accessrestrict.p: The collection is open for research.
